headline: Ford Takes $19.5 Billion Hit as It Pivots to Hybrids, Trucks, and Energy Storage
summary: Ford is redeploying capital away from large EVs toward hybrids, trucks, and battery energy storage to improve profitability and align with customer demand.

headline: How Renault’s Long‑Term Ford EV Supply Deal At Renault (ENXTPA:RNO) Has Changed Its Investment Story
summary: In December 2025, Renault Group and Ford announced a long-term European collaboration under which Renault’s Ampere platform and ElectriCity plants in northern France will develop and build two Ford‑branded electric cars, with the first model expected to reach showrooms in early 2028. The partnership not only deepens Renault’s role as an EV technology and manufacturing supplier, but also explores joint light commercial vehicle development, potentially broadening Renault’s revenue...

content.title: How Renault’s Long‑Term Ford EV Supply Deal At Renault (ENXTPA:RNO) Has Changed Its Investment Story
content.summary: In December 2025, Renault Group and Ford announced a long-term European collaboration under which Renault’s Ampere platform and ElectriCity plants in northern France will develop and build two Ford‑branded electric cars, with the first model expected to reach showrooms in early 2028. The partnership not only deepens Renault’s role as an EV technology and manufacturing supplier, but also explores joint light commercial vehicle development, potentially broadening Renault’s revenue...

headline: Ford retreats from EVs, takes $19.5 billion charge as Trump policies grip autos
summary:
STORY: Ford is stopping several of its electric-vehicle models and will take a $19.5 billion writedown.

That was the word from the U.S. auto major on Monday (December 15).

It's the strongest sign yet of the auto industry's pullback from battery-powered models.

Ford said it will replace the full electric F-150 Lightning with a new extended-range electric model that uses a gas-powered engine to recharge the battery.

The company also cancelled a next-generation electric truck, code-named the T3, as well as planned electric commercial vans.

Ford CEO Jim Farley said the market changed over the last couple of months and drove the carmaker's decision.

Adding that it will pivot hard into gas and hybrid models, and eventually hire thousands of workers.

The company expects its global mix of hybrids, extended-range EVs and pure EVs to reach 50% by 2030 - up from 17% today.

The outlook for electrics dimmed this year as U.S. President Donald Trump’s policies pulled federal support for EVs.

Trump also eased tailpipe-emissions rules, which could encourage carmakers to sell more gas-powered cars.

U.S. sales of electric vehicles fell about 40% in November - that followed the end of a $7,500 consumer tax credit in September.

Ford isn't alone in changing its approach to EVs.

General Motors took a $1.6 billion charge in October as it adjusted its EV factory plans.

While Stellantis also backtracked on some of its EV plans and leaned into hybrids.

Ford also said Monday it will spread out the multi-billion dollar writedown over a few quarters.

And it raised its guidance for this year's adjusted earnings before interest and taxes, to about $7 billion.

That was up from a previous range of $6 billion to $6.5 billion.

content.title: Ford retreats from EVs, takes $19.5 billion charge as Trump policies grip autos

headline: Ford takes $19.5 billion hit as it pulls back on electric vehicle plans, halts F-150 Lightning production
summary: Ford on Monday said it is pulling back on its electric vehicle plans, a move that will result in a $19.5 billion charge against its earnings to be taken mostly in the current quarter.

content.title: Ford takes $19.5 billion hit as it pulls back on electric vehicle plans, halts F-150 Lightning production
content.summary: Ford on Monday said it is pulling back on its electric vehicle plans, a move that will result in a $19.5 billion charge against its earnings to be taken mostly in the current quarter.

thumbnail.caption: Ford's electric F-150 Lightning on the production line in Dearborn, Michigan, in September. The company announced it is halting production of this version of the Lightning, without saying when it will restart production of the electric pick-up. - Jeff Kowalsky/AFP/Getty Images

headline: US markets inch down modestly ahead of latest government data on jobs, inflation
summary: Wall Street inched slightly lower early Tuesday ahead of the release of U.S. employment and inflation reports that could drive the direction of interest rates.  Nasdaq futures lost 0.2%.  Shares in Roomba maker iRobot sank more than 20% in premarket trading after the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

content.title: US markets inch down modestly ahead of latest government data on jobs, inflation
content.summary: Wall Street inched slightly lower early Tuesday ahead of the release of U.S. employment and inflation reports that could drive the direction of interest rates.  Nasdaq futures lost 0.2%.  Shares in Roomba maker iRobot sank more than 20% in premarket trading after the company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

headline: 3 Unpopular Stocks That Fall Short
summary: When Wall Street turns bearish on a stock, it’s worth paying attention. These calls stand out because analysts rarely issue grim ratings on companies for fear their firms will lose out in other business lines such as M&A advisory.

content.title: 3 Unpopular Stocks That Fall Short
content.summary: When Wall Street turns bearish on a stock, it’s worth paying attention. These calls stand out because analysts rarely issue grim ratings on companies for fear their firms will lose out in other business lines such as M&A advisory.
